title: William Rodwell
text:
William Hunter Rodwell (18 April 1850 – 3 August 1929) was an <a href="English%20people">English</a> first-class <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er and barrister.
The son of the politician and lawyer <a href="Benjamin%20Rodwell">Benjamin Rodwell</a>, he was born at <a href="Marylebone">Marylebone</a> in April 1850. He was educated at <a href="Harrow%20School">Harrow School</a>, before going up to <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity College, Cambridge</a>. Rodwell served in the <a href="Suffolk%20Yeomanry">West Suffolk Yeomanry</a>, being commissioned as a <a href="Cornet%20%28rank%29">cornet</a> in November 1868, before being promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> in January 1870. Four years later he was promoted to <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> in July 1874. A student of the <a href="Middle%20Temple">Middle Temple</a> in May 1872, Rodwell was <a href="Call_to_the_bar%23England_and_Wales">called to the bar</a> to practice as a barrister in April 1875. A year after he was called to the bar, Rodwell resigned his commission with the West Suffolk Yeomanry. He played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for the <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a> (MCC) in 1882, making a single appearance against <a href="Somerset%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Somerset</a>. He batted twice in the match, scoring 1 run in the MCC first innings before being dismissed by <a href="William%20Herbert%20Fowler">Herbert Fowler</a>, while in their second innings he was dismissed for 31 runs by <a href="Charles%20Winter%20%28cricketer%2C%20born%201866%29">Charles Winter</a>. Rodwell returned to the Suffolk Yeomanry in December 1880 holding the rank of captain, but resigned his commission again in May 1892, at which point he was granted the honorary rank of <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a>. He was additionally a <a href="Justice_of_the_peace%23England_and_Wales">justice of the peace</a> for <a href="Suffolk">Suffolk</a>. Rodwell died at <a href="Amersham">Amersham</a> in August 1929.
